messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:36): can someone explain what SPAM-LOW means?
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:37): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i'll bet it's a spam filter adding something to the subject header

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: my guess is that Schinkel got offended when it was pointed out to him that he both complained about mail volume and originated not-so-useful mail
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: looks intentional to me
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: but what does it mean?
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:38): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: oh, i guess i see it all over google mail list archives
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): oh
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:38): maybe it isn't then
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:39): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: unless mike likes to talk on all of those mailing lists
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:39): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I though he was pre-labeling his stuff as spam as a demonstration
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:40): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I emailed Mike about that
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:40): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: I may be wrong, but those labels appeared immediately after Schinkel was contacted off-list about the mail volume
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:40): I'm guessing it's his own spam software
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:40): it's annoying.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:40): I was wrong then
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:41): strange people
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:41): I think it's a simple oversight on his part
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:41): though very glaring in Gmail because it destroys the threading
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:41): Gmail needs to use jwz threading
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:41): is a canvas tag or other vector graphics feature in the charter for HTML5?
b406b22e31ce6e541c3754a7214cec1c (01:41): seems quite common: http://www.google.com/search?q=spam-low
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:41): or rather the HTML WG version of HTML5?

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:41): There are systems like http://www.dotnetted.co.uk/support/dotnetted/spam_virus_filtering.asp that apparently add SPAM-LOW to the subject line to indicate spamminess (I guess so mail clients can filter it easily), and presumably he doesn't remove that when responding
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:42): terrible :\
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:42): i swear, 90% of developers wouldn't know good software if it hit them square in the face
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:43): maybe that's a conservative estimate
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:44): It didn't occur to me that filters would tamper with the subject instead of putting filterable flags in a custom header
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (01:45): never underestimate the power of idiots writing software?
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:50): so no vector graphics in HTMLWG?
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:50): does that all go into SVG?

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:50): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: I think the charter isn't the place for mentioning specific features like that - but I don't see why canvas wouldn't be included, seeing as it's already specified and implemented widely
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:50): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: it is as yet undecided

d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:51): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: ah... i guess i'm wondering if we will rev canvas to suit the 2010 timeframe for this spec...
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:52): how do you mean?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:52): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: what do mean? No <canvas>? No SVG namespace special casing with the parsing algorithm?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:52): the timeframe in the charter is a joke
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:52): i wouldn't worry about it too much
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:52): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-archive/2006Nov/0001.html has a more realistic timetable

d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: i guess i mean, how forward looking should HTMLWG be w.r.t. canvas? i'd hate for this iteration of canvas to be it for the next 5 years
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: holy crap, that's far out in the future

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:54): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: <canvas> is available today. over time we may add more features, that might be in html6. I expect that eventually HTML5 and HTML6 will be developed in paralell.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:54): 2022 is not that far out in the future. consider that html4 came out 9 years ago and still hasn't reached the last step of that timetable (it's stuck in the CR step)
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (01:54): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: is HTML6 in WHATWG or in HTMLWG?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:54): (though formally the w3c has ignored that)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:55): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: it's a hypothetical spec, doesn't exist yet. i'm just saying that whoever does work on html6 will probably work on it in parallel with html5
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:55): near the end of the cycle they are bound to overlap

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:56): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: IIRC, at one point tantek was extracting testable assertions from HTML 4.01. did that do anywhere? did the WG drop the ball?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:56): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: you're asking if the xhtml wg dropped the ball on something? do i really need to answer that question?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (01:57): but tantek *was* extracting testable assertions, right?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:57): yeah

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (01:58): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: The canvas implementations are already being extended before any standardisation, e.g. with 3D in Firefox/Opera, so I'd expect it's unlikely that we'll be stuck with unchanging implementations for five years
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (02:05): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: i wonder where the best place to influence implementations would be then...
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (02:05): since after reading Canvas, there might be a few things i'd change to help improve it
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (02:07): The WHATWG mailing list seems to be the place for that kind of discussion at the moment
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (02:07): (fires up mailing list manager)
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:13): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: if you look at the html4 test suite, it includes a methodology document that explains what procedure he supposedly used

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:14): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: but if you look at the testable assertions cited for test cases, some of them are not recognizable as such even with his extended semantics

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:16): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: for instance some test cases cite sentences that appear to be conformance requirements for content, or that use the word "may"

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:23): if you want to read the html4 spec with an eye to making a test suite or an interoperable implementation, you'll need so much salt that it'll have a distint affect on the worldwide salt prices.
587bf8b858e15d03428e1415c33c38ef (02:25): is away: family time
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:26): I get no end of amusement that the definition of "conforming user agent" at http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/conform.html contradicts itself
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (02:26): i sense some frustration
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:26): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: nah, more amusement now. these problems are mostly solved in html5.
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (02:27): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: indeed (sadly looks at the SVG spec)
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (02:27): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: maybe WHATWG can start a SVG2 spec?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:28): SVG5 is further down the agenda
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:29): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e: well, there's no real plan for it, but if the SVG WG doesn't fix it, someone else will have to
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (02:30): rolls up his sleeves.
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (02:32): d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e, there's also some talk of XML5, HTTP5 and everything else that's currently broken
d14501081968ac6c4c1ee55a835b7e5e (02:32): interesting!
a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (02:32): We're moving from Web 2.0 to 5.0!

a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4 (02:35): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: what is it exactly that's contradictory in that?  Is it just the statment about arbitrary limits that contradicts the capacities in the SGML Decl?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:41): a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4: it says:

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:41): a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4: "A conforming user agent for HTML 4 is one that observes the mandatory conditions ("must") set forth in this specification, including the following points: A user agent should..."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:42): should means you don't have to do it if you have good reason not to. but it says if you don't do it you're not conforming.

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:42): a03bfa2a78d00389c65221c74759cbb4: it says a user againt must follow all mandatory conditions including... and then lists two that by the keywords are non-mandatory
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:42): there's also a "recommend" in their three bullet points
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:43): yeah
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (02:43): so I don't know how you would ever decide if those are valid testable assertions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:44): i do
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:44): you'd check the html5 spec :-D
